projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ORDINANCE FOR Better Amending AND Keeping in Repair THE COMMON HIGH-WAIES WITHIN THIS NATION.

figure.figDesc: depiction of the state arms of the Commonwealth (1649-60) consisting of the cross of St. George (patron saint of England) and the Irish harp

div.p: ORdered by His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, and his Council, That this Ordinance be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed.

closer.signed: HENRY SCOBELL Clerk of the Council

div.p: London, Printed by William du-Gard and Henry Hills, Printers to His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, 1654.

figure.figDesc: depiction of the state arms of the Commonwealth (1649-60) consisting of the cross of St. George (patron saint of England) and the Irish harp

div.head: AN ORDINANCE For better amending and keeping in repair THE Common High-Waies within this NATION.
div.p:
WHereas the ≈øeueral Statutes now in force for mending High-waies are found by experience not to haue produced ≈øuch Good Reformation as was thereby intended, Therefore, and to the end more effectual Remedies may be provided,
Be it ordained by His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, by and with the advice and con≈øent of his Council,
I. That in every Pari≈øh within this Nation of England and Wales, there be two or more (according to the Greatne≈øs of the Pari≈øh) able and ≈øufficient Hous-houlders inhabiting in ≈øuch Pari≈øh, and ≈øeverally holding Lands there of the yearly value of twenty pounds or more, in occupation, or ≈øuch others as ≈øhall be worth one hundred pounds in per≈øonal E≈øtate, elected and cho≈øen, upon the fir≈øt Tue≈øday next en≈øuing the five and twentieth day of March, yearly, to be Surveyors of the High-waies within their Re≈øpective Pari≈øhes for the year en≈øuing.
II. That if it ≈øhall fall out that no ≈øuch Surveyors ≈øhall be cho≈øen, as afore≈øaid, within any ≈øuch Pari≈øh, that then in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Pari≈øhioners of every ≈øuch Pari≈øh ≈øhall forfeit twenty pounds to be levyed upon the mo≈øt Sub≈øtantial Inhabitants thereof, who are to have contribution from all the re≈øt of the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh who are taxable hereby for repair of the ≈øaid High-waies; and in ca≈øe of difference in rating, the ≈øame to be ordered and ≈øettled by the Iu≈øtices of the Peace of the ≈øaid County, City or Town Corporate, where ≈øuch Pari≈øh lyes, or any two of them; and in ≈øuch ca≈øe where no ≈øuch election of Surveyors ≈øhall be made as afore≈øaid, the then Over≈øeers for the Poor of that Pari≈øh are hereby appointed to be Surveyors of the ≈øaid Surveyors
of the ≈øaid High-waies within ≈øuch Pari≈øh, for the year en≈øuing.
III. That every Per≈øon being elected, or hereby appointed to be Surveyors of High-waies, as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall undertake the Office, and ≈øhall within ten daies after ≈øuch his Election, or being appointed, as afore≈øaid, procure him≈øelf to be ≈øworn before ≈øome Iu≈øtice of Peace of the County, Riding, City, or Town Corporate, or Limit, within which his Pari≈øh doth ly, diligently and faithfully to execute the office of Surveyor of High-waies within his Pari≈øh for the year then en≈øuing, and faithfully to accompt for all moneys which ≈øhall come to his hands by vertue of his ≈øaid Office, which oath every Iu≈øtice of Peace is hereby impowred and authorized to admini≈øter, within the Limits of his Commi≈ø≈øion, accordingly. And if any ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øo elected, or hereby appointed, ≈øhall refu≈øe to accept of his ≈øaid Office, and to procure him≈øelf to be ≈øworn as afore≈øaid, that then every per≈øon ≈øo failing ≈øhall forfeit for the ≈øame the ≈øum of ten pounds.
IV. That every Surveyor of High waies, having accepted the Office, and being Sworn as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall diligently apply him≈øelf to the duty and Execution of his Office, and ≈øhall within ten daies after his Oath taken, view all the Common and Publique High-waies and Roads, where Carts and Carriages u≈øually pa≈øs, and all Common Bridges belonging to the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, to repair,
and all Water-cour≈øes, as al≈øo all Streets, and pavements, and Common Nu≈øances in the ≈øaid Waies and Streets, within their re≈øpective Pari≈øhes; And ≈øhall con≈øider what Reparations will be needfull to be made, and what ≈øummes of money will be requi≈øite and nece≈ø≈øary to be rai≈øed within the Pari≈øh for amending and repairing the ≈øame, upon pain of forfeiting twenty ≈øhillings a piece for neglect of ≈øuch view.
V. That the ≈øaid Surveyors do, within ≈øix daies after ≈øuch view, give publique notice in the Church or Chappel to the Pari≈øhioners to meet to make an A≈ø≈øe≈øment for repairing the ≈øaid High-waies & ≈øtreets, for making & repairing of pavements, and for clean≈øing the ≈øaid Streets and pavements, from time to time, and for what el≈øe ≈øhall be requi≈øite for the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, and thereupon a Rate or Tax in writing, within three daies after ≈øuch notice, ≈øhall be laid by the ≈øaid Inhabitants pre≈øent at ≈øuch meeting, or the greater number of them, by a pound Rate, upon all the ≈øeveral Occupiers of Hou≈øes, Lands, Tythes, Cole mines, fellable Woods, Tenements or Hereditaments, within the Pari≈øh, according to the true yearly value of the ≈øame, and al≈øo upon the dead Goods, Commodities or Stock in Trade of every particular Pari≈øhioner charged to pay to the poor, rating every twenty pounds value of ≈øuch Goods, equal to every twenty ≈øhillings Land by year; And ≈øuch further Rate to be afterward, and oftner made, as occa≈øion shall require, ≈øo as all the Rates together do
not exceed twelve pence in the pound for any one Pari≈øh in any one year.
VI. That if ≈øuch Pari≈øhioners, or the greater number of them, ≈øhall not agree among them≈øelves to make ≈øuch Rate within two daies after ≈øuch meeting, that then the ≈øaid Surveyors of High-waies them≈øelves ≈øhall make a Rate in writing according to the direction afore≈øaid, and ≈øuch Rate as the ≈øaid Pari≈øhioners or Surveyors re≈øpectively ≈øhall ≈øo make, being confirmed by one Iu≈øtice of peace, ≈øhall ≈øtand, until upon complaint and proof of ≈øome Irregularity or Inequality therein, to the Iu≈øtices of Peace at the Ses≈øions, the Bench of Iu≈øtices, or any two of them then pre≈øent ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe to alter the ≈øame; And if the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices ≈øhall find cau≈øe to alter it, then the ≈øaid Rate, with ≈øuch alteration as they ≈øhall make, ≈øhall ≈øtand without any further Appeal.
VII. That in ca≈øe where Common Nu≈øances are in High-waies, or where ≈øuch Common High-waies in any Pari≈øh are ≈øtreightned by rea≈øon of inclo≈øures made within twenty years, either by Hedges, Ditches, Walls, or the like, or where Ditches or Water cour≈øes adjoining upon ≈øuch High-waies, or which do lead the water from ≈øuch High-waies are not ≈øcoured and dre≈ø≈øed, or where any pavements are defective, or any Nu≈øances by filth or otherwi≈øe are in any paved Streets, the ≈øaid Surveyors ≈øhall ≈øee that the ≈øame be reformed, and the Offenders in any of the premi≈ø≈øes puni≈øht according to Law, by Information
or Indictments, deducting for the charge of pro≈øecution out of the monys collected; and the ≈øaid Pari≈øhioners or Surveyors of High-waies re≈øpectively are hereby impowred in ≈øuch ca≈øe al≈øo to impo≈øe and leavy over and above the twelve pence in the pound beforementioned, ≈øuch greater Taxes and Rates upon the Occupiers of tho≈øe Lands where ≈øuch Inclo≈øures, or Vndre≈øt Ditches or Fences be, as they ≈øhall re≈øpectively think fit, having the ≈øame Rates allowed by the Se≈ø≈øions of the peace, or the two next Iu≈øtices of peace, as afore≈øaid, which ≈øhall be final to the parties.
VIII. That if any Pari≈øhioners rated to the mending of High-waies as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall fail to pay to the ≈øaid Surveyors of High-waies his proportion of Tax rated upon him, by the ≈øpace of ≈øeaven daies after publique notice and warning given for payment thereof, That then every ≈øuch Pari≈øhioner failing shall pay double as much as he is rated at in the Tax.
IX. That for more effectual mending the ≈øaid High-waies, and parish-Bridges, and Streets, & for removing publique Nu≈øances out of the ≈øame, The Surveyors aforementioned shall yearly at ≈øuch convenient times as they shal agree upon, hire ≈øuch, and ≈øo many Labourers and Workmen, and Carts and Carriages, as they shall think needful for mending the ≈øaid High-waies, parish-Bridges, and Water-cour≈øes, and Streets, and shall cau≈øe them to be fully and perfeccly mended from
time to time, and ≈øuch Workmen and Owners of Carts and Carriages are hereby required to work accordingly, for ≈øuch rea≈øonable Wages, and under ≈øuch penalty, as any two Iu≈øtices of peace within the Divi≈øion shall think fit.
X. That in places where Ditches adjoyning to common High-ways, or ≈øerving to lead the water from ≈øuch High-ways, are or ≈øhall be undre≈øt or un≈øcoured, or where water doth run into or ≈øtand in any ≈øuch High-ways, to the annoyance of it, or where Trees, Bu≈øhes, or Hedges, ≈øtanding in High-ways, or adjoyning to High ways, are ≈øuffered to grow up, and to hinder and ob≈øcure it from the power of the Sun for drying thereof, The ≈øaid Surveyors are hereby impowred in all ≈øuch re≈øpective places to cau≈øe ≈øuch Ditches to be dre≈øt and ≈øcoured, and to ≈øtop and divert any ≈øuch water-cour≈øe, and to turn the water into any adjoyning Ditch, or to make new Ditches in convenient places through the Grounds adjoyning, for the mo≈øt convenient conveying ≈øuch water, as al≈øo to cut, pla≈øh, and keep low all ≈øuch Trees, Bu≈øhes, and Hedges, as they ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe.
XI. That the ≈øaid Surveyors be & are hereby impowred further to dig for and get Stones, Gravel, Sand, Sinder, Chalk, or any other material fit for mending High ways in or upon any the wa≈øt or common Grounds within the Pari≈øh, or if they cannot there be conveniently had, in and upon any private mans Pa≈øture or fallow
Ground where it may be had, within the Pari≈øh, or in any other near adjoyning Pari≈øh, with convenient way for ≈øending the ≈øame at ≈øuch ≈øea≈øonable times, and for ≈øuch rea≈øonable ≈øatisfaction and compo≈øition to ≈øuch private per≈øon as the ≈øaid Surveyors and Occupiers of ≈øuch Land ≈øhall agree upon, and in ca≈øe of di≈øagreement betwixt them, then for ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction as any Iu≈øtice of Peace near adjoyning, not intere≈ø≈øed in ≈øuch Ground, to be indifferently cho≈øen by the parties, ≈øhall ≈øet down and appoint, and ≈øuch Order as the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices of Peace ≈øhall ≈øet down ≈øhall be final to the parties, without further appeal.
XII. That in ca≈øe where the ≈øaid common High-ways and ≈øtreets are or ≈øhall be ≈øo defective, or ≈øhall extend in ≈øo great length in any one Pari≈øh as that the parish is overburdened therewith, and the Rate of twelve-pence in the pound before mentioned will not ≈øuffice to amend and repair the ≈øame, the Iu≈øtices of Peace, at their open Se≈ø≈øions, are hereby impowred from time to time to rate ≈øuch other parishes within the Limits of their Commi≈ø≈øion, who≈øe Rate for mending High-ways according to the true yearly value of the Land shall not amount to twelve pence in the pound as afore≈øaid, as the ≈øaid Iu≈øtice shall think fit, till the Rate amount to twelve-pence in the pound, towards the mending of the High-ways and ≈øtreets in ≈øuch parishes as they shall finde to be ≈øo overburdened.
XIII. That if any Wagons, Carts, or Carriages, wherein any Burdens of dead Commodities or Wares shall at any time from and after the fir≈øt day of M ‚Ä¢ y next be drawn upon any ≈øuch High-ways, Roads, or ≈øtreets with above five hor≈øes or Mares, or ≈øix Oxen and one hor≈øe or Mare, in any one Cart or Wagon, that then it shall be lawfull to or for any Con≈øtable or Surveyor of High-ways, or other Inhabitant in any parish where ≈øuch loaden Wagon, Cart, or Carriage shall pa≈øs, and be drawn as afore≈øaid, to di≈øtrain and ≈øeize all ≈øuch ≈øupernumerary hor≈øes, Mares, or Oxen, as he shall finde in any ≈øuch Wagon, Cart, or Carriage, over and above the number of five hor≈øes or Mares, or ≈øix Oxen and one hor≈øe or Mare re≈øpectively, & the ≈øame ≈øupernumerary Hor≈øes, Oxen and Mares re≈øpectively, to detain and keep until ≈øuch Owner or Driver have paid and an≈øwered into the hands of the ≈øurveyors of High-waies within the pari≈øh where ≈øuch Di≈øtre≈ø≈øe and ≈øeizure shall be made, or one of them, the ≈øum of twenty shillings for every ≈øuch ≈øupernumerary Hor≈øe Mare, or Ox; And if ≈øuch penalty be not paid within ≈øeven daies after ≈øuch Di≈øtre≈øs or ≈øeizure, together with full ≈øatisfaction for
keeping the Bea≈øts and Cattle di≈øtrained, and other Charges thereabouts in the mean time, that then it shall be lawful for ≈øuch ≈øurveyors of High waies to ≈øell ≈øuch Hor≈øes, Mares, or Oxen ≈øo ≈øeized, and to retain out of the price the ≈øaid twenty shillings and charges, returning the overplus to the partie. And in ca≈øe any difference happen about the ≈øame, the Next Iu≈øtice of Peace shall determine the ≈øame, who≈øe Order therein shal be final to each partie.
XIV. That the Iu≈øtices of peace at their open ≈øe≈ø≈øions shall be, and are hereby enable and enjoined, to enquire after, hear, and determine all Matters concerning any Charitable Gifts, for the making, amending, and keeping in repair any Common High waies, pavements, ≈øtreets, cau≈øeys, or Bridges, within the Limits of their Commi≈ø≈øion, as well where ≈øpecial Vi≈øitors and Over≈øeers are appointed, as otherwi≈øe, and make Orders and Decrees for the due imployment of ≈øuch Charitable Gifts according to the true intent of the Donors thereof.
as fully as any Commi≈ø≈øioners for Charitable u≈øes may do; and in ca≈øe they ≈øhall finde any wilful neglect or mi≈øimployment in any per≈øon or per≈øons, bodie politick or corporate, in or concerning the ≈øame, the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices ≈øhall and may over and above the ordering and decreeing what ≈øhall bee due and in arrear, with damage for not imploying the ≈øaid charitable gift according to the true intent thereof, impo≈øe a Fine, not exceeding fourtie pounds, upon ≈øuch as ≈øhall bee found offendors therein; which Fine, in ca≈øe of refu≈øal to bee paid within fourtie daies of the demand made by Warrant from the Iu≈øtices, or any two of them, ≈øhall bee Levied by Warrant from the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices, by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of the offenders goods, and being Levied, ≈øhall by the care of the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices bee imployed for the mending and repairing the ≈øaid Highwayes, Pavements, Streets, Bridges, or Cau≈øies re≈øpectively; And ≈øuch order as the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices ≈øhall make in the premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øhall bee final without further appeal.
XV. That Streets and Pavements in any Citie, Town-Corporate, or the Suburbs thereof, or near adjoyning to the ≈øame, are hereby declared to bee Common Highwayes, and Scavengers to bee Surveyors, within the intent and con≈øtruction of this Ordinance, and within all Laws in force concerning Highwayes, and in every Pari≈øh and
place where Pavements and Streets are, they ≈øhall bee Paved and kept in good repair, and clean≈øed for the conveniencie and health of the Inhabitants; And where any of the Provi≈øions afore-mentioned, or any other Laws now in force concerning Highwayes, Streets or Pavements, ≈øhall not bee found ≈øufficient to reform the great defects of Pavements and Water-cour≈øes, and in removing of filth and other nu≈øances in ≈øuch Streets and places; it ≈øhall and may bee lawful to and for the Inhabitants of any ≈øuch Pari≈øh rated to the poor, to meet together at the time hereby appointed, for choice of Surveyors, or Scavengers; at which time, or as often as the ≈øaid Inhabitants ≈øhall plea≈ø, they ≈øhall ≈øet down and make ≈øuch rea≈øonable by-laws and orders, for the rating and taxing the ≈øeveral Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, being occupiers of any Hou≈øes, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or having any Stock or Trade or otherwi≈øe, being of ≈øufficient abilitie for reforming the defects in Paving and clean≈øing the Streets, and cau≈øing the Channels and Water-cour≈øes to run freely, and for keeping the ≈øame in good order, and for a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing and impo≈øing rea≈øonable penalties upon offendors, and for Levying of the ≈øaid ≈øeveral ≈øums by Warrant of any Iu≈øtice of Peace, within the limits of his Commi≈ø≈øion, by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the offendors goods, and for imploying the ≈øame, and reforming the neglect of Scavengers and Inhabitants in any the premi≈ø≈øes, as they ≈øhall think fit; which Orders ≈øo make, being pre≈øented
unto, and allowed, or altered by the Iu≈øtices of Peace at their open Se≈ø≈øions, ≈øhall bee duly ob≈øerved and put in execution, according to the allowance or alteration of the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices of Peace, and bee final to all parties.
XVI. That all ≈øums of money A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and Rated as afore≈øaid, and all fines, penalties, forfeiture, and other ≈øums of money ari≈øing by A≈ø≈øe≈øment or otherwi≈øe, by this Ordinance, or by any other Law now in force, touching Highwayes and Streets, and all I≈ø≈øues to bee forfeited for not appearing to any Information or Indictment, for not repairing any Highwayes, or not remooving or reforming defects and Nu≈øances in any Streets or Highwayes; And all Fines or Amercements, to bee impo≈øed upon any Pari≈øh or private per≈øon, for not repairing Highwayes, Streets or Water-cour≈øes, ≈øhall bee imployed and be≈øtowed by the ≈øaid Surveyors of Highways, in paying Workmen's Wages for doing ≈øuch works, and for ≈øuch other imployment as are hereby appointed to bee don and performed, and ≈øhall be Levied by virtue of this Ordinance by the ≈øaid Surveyors of Highwayes, or any of them, by Warrant from any Iu≈øtice of Peace within the Countie, Riding, Citie, Town-Corporate, or limit of his Commi≈ø≈øion, by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of the goods of ≈øuch per≈øon as ≈øhall bee ≈øo behinde, or chargeable with any ≈øuch ≈øum;
and for default of ≈øuch di≈øtre≈øs or non-payment of the money by the ≈øpace of ten days after demand thereof made or left at his hou≈ø in Writeing under the hand of the ≈øaid Surveyors, or either of them, the partie ≈øo in arrear, ≈øhall bee by Warrant from any Iu≈øtice of Peace within the ≈øaid Divi≈øion, committed to pri≈øon to the Common-Goal of the Countie, there to remain without Bail or Mainpri≈øe, till hee have paid double what ≈øhall bee ≈øo in arrear, and charged upon him to pay, together with the charges incurred to parties pro≈øecuting by ≈øuch default.
XVII. That if any ≈øuit ≈øhall bee commen≈øed by any per≈øon again≈øt any Con≈øtable or Surveyors of Highwayes, or again≈øt any per≈øon imployed by them, or any of them, or authorized by this Ordinance, to do or perform, as by this Ordinance is directed, for doing and performing as afore≈øaid; that then in every ≈øuch ca≈øe, the Action ≈øhall bee laid in the proper County where the fact was don, and not el≈øwhere; and the Defendant may plead the general I≈ø≈øue to it, and give the ≈øpecial matter in evidence at the Trial, That what was don, was don in pur≈øuance of this Ordinance; and if upon examination it ≈øhall ≈øo appear to bee don, then the Iurie ≈øhall finde for the Defendant: And in ≈øuch ca≈øe, as al≈øo if the Plantiff ≈øhall bee non≈øuit, or di≈øcontinue his Action after the Defendant hath appeared, the Defendant ≈øhall have his full co≈øts, which upon Oath hee
≈øhall make appear to the Iudge before whom the Trial or di≈øcontinuance is had, hee hath laid out in defence of ≈øuch ≈øuit, and al≈øo ten pounds more, in regard of his unju≈øt trouble and vexation, taxed by the Court, again≈øt ≈øuch Plantiff.
XVIII. That every Surveyor elected or hereby appointed as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall yearly within one moneth after the expiration of the year, wherein hee was ≈øo Surveyor, make & yield up to the Pari≈øhioners of the Pari≈øh, a true and perfect account in writing, at ≈øom publick meeting to bee appointed by the Pari≈øh, of all the moneys hee hath received or paid out within his year, for or by rea≈øon of his ≈øaid office; namely, of whom, and what received, and to whom, and what paid; and if any overplus do remain in his hands, hee ≈øhall pay the ≈øame over to the next Surveyors then in beeing, for the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, to bee disbur≈øed in and about the Highwayes: And if ≈øuch Surveyors, ≈øhall refu≈øe or neglect to make ≈øuch account or repayment as afore≈øaid, that then it ≈øhall bee lawful to and for any Iu≈øtice of Peace within the Countie, Riding, Citie, Town-Corporate, or limit where the Pari≈øh lie's, to examin the Account, and upon default found on the Surveyor's part, to commit ≈øuch Surveyor to the Common-Goal of the Countie, there to remain without Bayl or Mainpri≈øe, until hee ≈øhall make ≈øuch Account, and payment as afore≈øaid, together
with ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction for the damage which the ≈øaid Pari≈øhioners have ≈øu≈øtained, by rea≈øon of ≈øuch neglect, as any ≈øuch Iu≈øtice of Peace ≈øhall adjudg rea≈øonable; But if the ≈øaid Iu≈øtice ≈øhall finde ≈øuch Account to bee clear and good, then hee is to allow the ≈øame, and ≈øuch Surveyor is not afterwards to bee que≈øtioned or troubled thereabouts: Provided always, that this Ordinance, nor any thing therein conteined, ≈øhall not extend to di≈øcharge any per≈øon or per≈øons, body-politick or corporate, from repairing or reforming any the defects and abu≈øes, as afore≈øaid, which by any Grant, Tenure, Pre≈øcription, Limitation or Appointment, of any Charitable Gifts, they are bound and charged to repair and reform, nor to alter or make void any Law or Cu≈øtom now in force, or u≈øed for the inforcing and con≈øtreining the ≈øaid per≈øons and bodies-politick, aforementioned, to perform and do their duties, in repairing ≈øuch Highwaies and Bridges as afore≈øaid. And it is the true intent and meaning of this Ordinance, that no Surveyors, for amendment of Highwaies, ≈øhall bee cho≈øen at any other time, or otherwi≈øe then by this Ordinance is directed. And it is further Ordeined, by the Authority afore≈øaid, That no Writ of Certiorari, ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue or bee allowed to remove any Information, Indictment, Pre≈øentment, or other proceedings, within this Ordinance, or within any Law now in force, concerning Highwayes, Cau≈øies, or Bridges, except it bee upon ≈øom que≈øtion and controver≈øie, betwixt Countie and Countie.

And it is la≈øtly Ordained, by the Authoritie afore≈øaid, That one Act made in the fir≈øt year of the Reign of the late Queen Mary, for, and concerning the making, repairing, and amendment of the Common-Highway and Cau≈øie, in the Counties of Dor≈øet and Somer≈øet, between the Towns of Shaftsburie and Shirborne, in the ≈øaid Countie of Dor≈øet, Intituled, An Act to Repair Shirborn-Cau≈øie, in the Counties of Dor≈øet and Somer≈øet, from henceforth ≈øhall bee revived and ≈øtand in force, until the fir≈øt of September, 1662.
ORdered by His Highne≈øs the Lord PROTECTOR and His Council, that this Ordinance bee forthwith Printed and Publi≈øhed.

closer.signed: HEN. SCOBEL, Clerk of the Council.

div.p: LONDON, Printed, by William Du-Gard, and Henry Hills, Printers to His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector. 1654.
